conceptual_confusion.now: Use fingers, sticks, or classroom objects to demonstrate the concept slowly and repeatedly.
conceptual_confusion.why: Young learners understand best through hands-on manipulation of real objects.
conceptual_confusion.next: Reinforce the idea using simple games and counting activities.

number_recognition.now: Display number cards and ask students to match numbers with quantities using objects.
number_recognition.why: Visual-number association strengthens early numeracy skills.
number_recognition.next: Practice number recognition through songs or flashcard games.

conceptual_confusion.now: Pause the activity and group students by understanding. Use physical objects like stones or chalk pieces to demonstrate the concept step by step.
conceptual_confusion.why: Concrete materials help students visualize abstract math concepts and reduce cognitive overload.
conceptual_confusion.next: Plan a short revision activity using everyday objects before introducing new concepts.

calculation_errors.now: Ask students to explain their steps aloud while solving a problem on the board.
calculation_errors.why: Verbalizing reasoning helps identify where misunderstandings occur.

abstract_reasoning.now: Use diagrams or simple real-life examples to bridge abstract concepts.
abstract_reasoning.why: Linking math to real situations improves comprehension at higher levels.

formula_confusion.now: Break the formula into parts and explain what each part represents.
formula_confusion.why: Understanding meaning prevents rote memorization errors.
formula_confusion.next: Give practice problems that focus on one part of the formula at a time.

reading_difficulty.now: Read aloud together and point to words as you read.
reading_difficulty.why: Shared reading builds word recognition and confidence.
reading_difficulty.next: Encourage students to identify familiar words in simple sentences.

student_disengagement.now: Switch to a quick oral storytelling or question-based interaction involving all students.
student_disengagement.why: Oral participation re-engages attention and builds confidence without reading pressure.
student_disengagement.next: Introduce pair-reading or role-play in the next lesson to sustain engagement.

vocabulary_gap.now: Introduce new words using pictures and simple examples.
vocabulary_gap.why: Contextual learning improves retention of vocabulary.
vocabulary_gap.next: Reinforce words through short writing or speaking activities.

grammar_confusion.now: Provide sentence examples and ask students to identify the grammatical pattern.
grammar_confusion.why: Pattern recognition helps internalize grammar rules.
